scenario (worst case scenario) and involves the release of 32,250 tons of ammonia.
This release must be considered to occur over a 10- minute period and pooling of the ammonia can be considered when modeling this release. EPA's RMP*COMP version 1.07 was used to determine the maximum downwind distance the ammonia release could impact the general public.
This assessment incorporated a toxic endpoint of 0.14 mg/L (Ammonia concentration) of 0.14 mg/L. This toxic endpoint of 0.14 mg/L refers to the maximum airborne concentration below which it is believed nearly all individuals could be exposed for up to one hour without experiencing or developing irreversible or other serious health effects or symptoms that could impair an individual's ability to take protective action.
An alternate scenario, which is a more likely event, is required to be submitted. The alternate case chosen involved the release of ammonia from a transfer pipe where 96,000 pounds would be released over a 2-minute period. A significantly lower quantity is involved because various shutdown safeguards have been installed and operator intervention will tend to mitigate and limit the quantity in such cases. The same modeling techniques were applied and resulted in much lesser off-site impact. Under average weather conditions of low/moderate wind speed and neutral atmospheric dispersion, the release will cause off-site impacts. The EPA’s RMP*COMP version 1.07 was also used to perform the off-site consequence analysis. The ammonia toxic endpoint of 0.14 mg/L was used in the assessment.
Black Point Personnel are committed to implementing, reviewing, and updating the facility's Process Safety Management Program to ensure the highest standards are met for the continued safe operation of the Ammonia Terminal.  In addition, Tampa Port Services, LLC will continue to provide support to and work with the Local Emergency Planning Committee and emergency responders to plan for the appropriate emergency response and

INCIDENT INVESTIGATION: 
A facility team promptly investigates any accident, near miss, or incident that resulted in, or could have resulted in, an ammonia release. Findings of the investigation team and their recommendations for corrective action are documented, as is the resolution of the recommendations and corrective actions.

COMPLIANCE AUDIT: 
The program is audited at least every three years to verify compliance with these procedures. Findings of the audit are documented, and any deficiencies are corrected and documented. 

5-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:
The Risk Management rule requires inclusion of the 5-year accident history of the facility for all accidental releases that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or any known off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage. There have been no reportable releases in the facility's last five years. However, a nonreportable release was recorded on July 2, 2013, for which a notification was submitted to the National Response Center, case number 701976. This release was less than 100 pounds of anhydrous ammonia.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAMS
HAZMAT training is performed in accordance with OSHA regulation 29 CFR 1910.120(q) and pre-emergency planning and drills are conducted with local emergency responders. The emergency response program complies with the OSHA PSM Program as outlined in 29 CFR 1910.119.

SYNOPSIS OF WORST AND ALTERNATE CASE RELEASE SCENARIOS:
The Risk Management rule requires a hazard analysis for worst-case and alternate case accidental release scenarios for regulated substances. The rule requires an analysis involving the release of the total contents of the largest storage vessel of ammonia at this site. This is called the worst case toxic release

ith safe operating limits, and equipment records and design requirements.

PROCESS HAZARD ANALYSIS: Contract employees, with extensive professional training in the methods of process hazard analysis (PHA), are retained to act as PHA team leaders and work in conjunction with the Terminal employees. These reviews are updated on a regular basis.

OPERATING PROCEDURES: 
Operating procedures are in place for all aspects of the operation, including emergency operation and shutdown.

OPERATIONS TRAINING: 
All operators receive initial training in the process and its operating procedures and are supervised by an experienced operator for a lengthy training period before being allowed to control the process on their own. 

CONTRACTORS: 
Contractor selection includes review of safety performance and programs. Contractors are also required to have had recent site-specific training from the facility. Periodic evaluations are made to assure that work is completed in a safe manner.

PRE-STARTUP REVIEW: 
A safety review is conducted on any new process equipment or any significant modification of the process. This assures that construction and equipment installed are in accordance with design, that all necessary procedures, including safety procedures, are in place, that necessary training is completed, and that hazard analysis or other requirements of management of change are completed.

MECHANICAL INTEGRITY: 
This is a quality assurance procedure to assure that equipment, parts, materials, and installations are suitable for the applications intended. Maintenance employees are trained in process hazards and safety procedures applicable to their work. Inspections, procedures, and testing are conducted under this part of the program.

SAFE WORK PRACTICES: 
Procedures and policies for all work permits and maintenance lockout/tagout procedures are in force and are periodically reviewed for completeness and effectiveness.

MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE: 
No changes in the process or procedures a

irst Responder level for ammonia release emergencies. The plan is designed to prevent employee exposure and to coordinate with local emergency response agencies in the event of a release. A shared community and plant emergency siren system is in operation and tested monthly. This plan is coordinated with the local community response plan and is available to those responding agencies. Emergency Planning and Community Right-To-Know information, as required under SARA Title III, has been provided to the State Emergency Response Commission, the Local Emergency Planning Committee, and the local fire department.

PREVENTION PROGRAM:                                                                                                             
The Black Point Ammonia Terminal is subject to OSHA Process Safety Management Rule and is therefore under the EPA Risk Management Rule. It is a Program 3 facility with a Program 3 Prevention Program. The OSHA PSM/EPA Prevention Program consists of a set of facility management policies and procedures that promote and recognize process safety and the prevention of accidents in plants that handle, use, store, and process hazardous chemicals above the threshold quantity specified. The procedures address all aspects of facility activities, including training, maintenance, operating procedures, process reviews, safe work practices, incident investigation, audits, and other activities in a manner to provide controls to prevent errors, failures, and inadvertent changes in a process which could result in accidents. The prevention program consists of many elements and policies, which are briefly outlined below. 
EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION: Employees participate in all aspects of the program and are provided with the information developed in the program.

PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION: 
All necessary process information and records are maintained in several convenient locations, including information on the hazards of the chemicals, process technology w

thods of recycling, treatment, and disposal. By preventing pollution at the source, we strive to achieve cost savings, increase operational efficiencies, and maintain a safe and healthy workplace.

STATIONARY SOURCEAND REGULATED SUBSTANCE:
The Black Point Ammonia Terminal serves as a vital link in supplying ammonia to its own manufacturing facilities and other customers. Black Point receives refrigerated anhydrous ammonia from ships at its unloading dock. Ammonia is pumped from the ship to low pressure storage tanks where the ammonia is refrigerated and stored at -28 °F. Black Point may also transfer ammonia via a privately owned pipeline for delivery to Mosaic facilities. The only substance regulated under EPA's RMP requirements at the facility is ammonia.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
Black Point has an extensive safety program to ensure compliance with all applicable local, state, and federal rules and regulations. The facility operates under a Corporate Environmental Health and Safety Policy that endorses going beyond regulatory requirements when necessary to protect the health and safety of its employees and the public. The design, maintenance and operation of the facility are carried out in conformance with this policy to provide a safe operation and to prevent exposures of our employees and nearby neighbors to ammonia. Management at the Black Point Ammonia Terminal is responsible for the development and implementation of programs and procedures to ensure conformance with this philosophy. The programs and procedures are continually reviewed and updated.                                                                                            
                                                                                                                                                     
The Black Point Terminal has always had a written Emergency Response Plan in effect, and all its employees are trained to the extent of F

RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
Tampa Port Services, LLC
Black Point Ammonia Terminal

EXECUTIVE UMMARY                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Tampa Port Services, LLC, a wholly owned subsidiary of The Mosaic Company, owns and operates the Black Point Ammonia Terminal. In this Tampa Port Services distribution facility, we handle anhydrous ammonia, which is considered hazardous by EPA. The same properties that make anhydrous ammonia valuable as a commodity also make it necessary to observe certain safety precautions in handling anhydrous ammonia to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the threat to our employees and site workers, and to reduce the threat to nearby members of the community. It is our policy to adhere to all applicable federal and state rules and regulations, and we are committed to conducting business and operating our facilities in a manner designed to protect the environment, and the health and safety of our employees, and our neighbors around the Ammonia Terminal. The facility is situated on Port Sutton Channel, with dock facilities for one ship, and storage tanks with the capacity for up to 49,000 tons of ammonia. The ammonia is in liquid form and is maintained at low temperature (-28° F) to keep the storage tank pressure below one pound per square inch.

POLLUTION PREVENTION POLICY:
Tampa Port Services, LLC, is committed to protecting the environment and preserving our natural resources for future generations. We strive to eliminate or reduce our use of toxic substances and to minimize our use of energy and the generation of all wastes to the extent technically and economically feasible.
